title: How to Build Better Habits in 4 Simple Steps
summary: All habits follow the same neurological pattern: cue, craving, response, reward. Good habits are formed by making each step easy and appealing, while bad habits are broken by making the steps difficult and unattractive. This is the backbone of the entire Atomic Habits system.
keyIdeas: The habit loop consists of cue, craving, response, reward.
The Four Laws of Behavior Change govern habit formation.
Make it obvious, make it attractive, make it easy, make it satisfying.
Cravings drive the habit loop forward.
Rewards teach your brain what to repeat.
Habit stacking links new habits to existing ones.
examples: Brushing your teeth after seeing your toothbrush in the bathroom (cue).
Checking your phone whenever you feel bored (craving).
exercises: Choose a habit and identify its cue, craving, response, and reward.
Create one habit stack using: 'After I ____, I will ____.'
reflections: Which cue triggers most of your bad habits?
What reward makes your best habit satisfying?
